title: In situ TEM Pyrolysis of Conductive 2D Coordination Polymers for Improved Application as Solid Acid Fuel Cell Electrode Materials
content: Solid acid fuel cells (SAFCs) offer long-term power output, high energy density, low maintenance costs, and high reliability, making them an attractive option for increasing energy demands [1]. However, the higher operating temperatures (150 – 300 °C) of the SAFC make traditional Pt- supported -on carbon- electrocatalyst ill-suited for direct translation from the state-of-the-art polymer electrolyte membrane fuel cell (PEMFC) to solid oxide fuel cells. Metal-organic coordination polymers meet the expansive and varied needs of a SAFC electrode [2] – thermal stability, chemical resistivity to the solid acid electrolyte corrosive environment, electrical conductivity, porosity to facilitate fuel mass transport, and catalytic ability towards hydrogen oxidation or oxygen reduction – thus making them one of the few options available for SAFC electrode materials [3]. Here we investigate a metal-organic hybrid precursor material suitable for pyrolysis in inert atmospheres to create metal-doped carbonized materials in pursuit of highly electrically conductive and porous carbonaceous materials to facilitate nano-Pt catalysis and gas transport toward a more robust solid acid fuel cell electrode material.
